author: kill0kong
body:
Thanks for the comment. Curious. What makes you say RDFN will be out of business?
My RDFN avg is $16 and is up pretty good from that point. I think it is better positioned in real estate market than other technology focussed companies like Zillow in the space. Its focus on tech and investments in expanding platform capabilities is amazing. IMO it is a slow but sure winner in real estate brokerage space.
My GWRE average is $79. GWRE is a monopoly in end to end cloud based solutions for large insurance companies. Insurance companies have just started investing in technology/ digital transformation for their processes and have a long way to go. GWRE is coupling its platform capabilities with AI/ML which allows for better CRM, risk management and pricing. I know few consultant friends who are making a killing in implementing this for their customers. The management is awesome as it is led by a former McKinsey partner who had worked in this space for 15 yrs or so.
Will take your word and buy more ADBE :)

author: diqster
body:
You're ignoring the wholesale component of datacenter operators. AWS and Azure "run their own datacenters", but not always. Frequently, they will wholesale lease entire datacenters from DRT or Equinix. This is especially the case for Facebook, Apple, Salesforce, etc. Massive players that will never do anything with the public cloud providers. This is not a zero sum game.

Do you think it's smaller companies that have pre-bought all of the space in Interxion Frankfurt's next 2 buildings before they broke ground? No, it's the hyperscale players.

author: dvdmovie1
body:
I don't know that anyone buys it but I'm surprised there hasn't been an activist investor in the name yet. Dorsey is a ho

If Verizon buys it it will probably be an eventual write-off (anyone remember Oath?) I see no reason for Netflix to buy it. Snap is a no. I don't really see the reasoning for a T or a Comcast to get into the social media business. With Disney, I believe Iger has said no. I doubt Apple would be interested and predicting Apple making a major purchase over the last decade has been a great way to be wrong.

Softbank throwing money at it is a maybe. I thought about Salesforce (which did show interest years ago until shareholders basically went, "what the fuck do you think you're doing?") but given Benioff's rallying against the evils of Facebook, is he going to try again to buy a social media company? Probably not. I think that's the other thing: social media attracts various controversies. 

If I'm a potential buyer, do I want to get into that and now become associated with it?

author: gizamo
body:
This ER blew me away. Our company did an analysis of Progress's software to determine if we should use any of it. The concensus was a near unanimous "Please, fucking, No". All of our devs hated everything they tested, and the pricing was idiotic compared to other similar and often better tools. Their beating anything is just proof how shitty some companies are at DDing their tech tools.     
      
That said, all of our devs also hate working with CRM, which is a money printing machine.

author: abcNYC
body:
Net revenue retention is another metric. Basically measures by how much revenue expanded/contracted in a period, ideally measured for a cohort of customers. Management will give just one number, but I've always wished they'd actually give the component metrics, namely churn and upsells.

Take a look at the Slack and Zoom S1s, my guess is you'll find a good amount of SaaS metrics in there. Salesforce should also have some (I know they talk about Billings, Bookings, Backlog, and other forward  indicators).

author: nbphotography87
body:
but that’s not where this exercise is supposed to give you an edge.  holding ITM/ATM leaps is just a leveraged synthetic long stock.  Nancy Pelosi is bullish on FB, CRM, and AMZN, like every other person with 3 brain cells is.  

Looking at her picks is no more useful than looking at a hedge fund’s holdings.  

The whole idea is that she *could* time the market or a specific name based on non-public information.  A 30 day reporting lag blows that whole theory up.

author: debsman20
body:
Yeah shorter expiration is every newbie's mistake. I played CRM last earnings on a short on week expiration and got burned. In hindsight I wish I had bought a month or two out I would have been printing by now when it recovered not lost.
Now my new play is 40/60 rule. Use 40% of the money to buy 2 weeks spy calls and 60% in 2 months or longer expiration. Rinse and repeat the 40% quickly while riding long with the 60% calls.

author: t3chb1zn3ss
body:
If you don't mind me asking, how many shares do you own?

Depending on what the size of your position is, you could sell now and diversify to limit your risk.  You could also hold and wait for things to turnaround.  

I do see Slack as being an acquisition target.  Any potential acquisition news/rumors would push this stock price back towards the $30s.

I wouldn't be surprised if Apple, Google, or Salesforce made a play for Slack.  It wouldn't shock me either if Microsoft decided to make a play for Slack.  They've acquired competition before.  Some of the apps I used to use that were acquired by Microsoft were Acompli, Wunderlist, and Sunrise Calendar.  

Slack also has a strategic partnership with Atlassian.  If I'm not mistaken, Atlassian sold some of their related IP to Slack, discontinued their competing product, and started redirecting their customers to Slack.  As Atlassian continues to grow, it wouldn't surprise me if they went back and acquired Slack.

Whatever you do, don't panic sell.  The market is hot right now, but it won't be like that forever.

TL;DR:  Be patient.  Hold.  If not, sell and diversify.  Slack is an attractive acquisition target.

author: 1f1nas
body:
Guys hi,

Could you help me understand why "Depreciation and amortization" is added back [here](https://puu.sh/EZ4uX/f7a8a4834b.png) when calculating net cash provided by operating activities though it it was not subtracted when calculating net income ?

Let's take year 2005

for example i understand adding back 590 of "Minority interest in consolidated joint venture" cause it was subtracted when calculating net income. But i don't see anywhere on statement of operations subtraction of "Depreciation and amortization" or "Amortization of deferred commissions", why are they added back on cash flow statement ?

(screen shot is from [CRM annual statement for 2005](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1108524/000119312505061027/d10k.htm#tx88114_4))
